articles.title: Show HN: I built a small OSS kernel for replaying and diffing AI decisions
articles.description:
Iâ€™ve been hacking on a small open-source project called Verist and figured Iâ€™d share it here to get some early feedback.

What kept bothering me with AI features in production wasnâ€™t really how to build them, but everything that comes after: explaining why something happened, reproducing it weeks later, or changing prompts/models without breaking things in subtle ways.

Logs helped a bit, but not enough. Agent frameworks felt too implicit for my taste. And model upgrades were honestly scary, outputs would change and it wasnâ€™t always obvious where or why.

So I ended up building a very small, explicit kernel where each AI step can be replayed, diffed, and reviewed. Think something like Git-style workflows for AI decisions, but without trying to be a framework or a runtime.

Itâ€™s not an agent framework, not a chat UI, and not a platform, just a TypeScript library focused on explicit state, audit events, and replay + diff.

Repo: https://github.com/verist-ai/verist

Iâ€™m especially curious if others here have run into similar issues shipping AI features to prod, or if this feels like overkill. Happy to answer questions or hear criticism.

Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46841302

We have thousands of pattern matching bots that were trained on human knowledge but on human behavior too. That means crimes, hacks, etc ...

They have a lot of technical knowledge, they're online 24/7, there's thousands of them, without any supervision. They can pretty much scan the internet for vulnerabilities 24/7.

This will end badly, well, actually this won't end, but there's gonna be major problems soon.

articles.title: Ask HN: Are retries the wrong abstraction under rate limits?
articles.description:
Over the last few years, Iâ€™ve watched a lot of production systems fail in ways that feelâ€¦ strangely predictable.

When services hit 429s or timeouts, the standard response is almost always the same: retries with backoff, sleep loops, jitter, etc. This is treated as a best practice across languages and platforms.

But in systems with high concurrency, fan-out, or shared downstream dependencies, retries often seem to amplify load instead of smoothing it. What starts as localized failure can turn into retry storms, thundering herds, and cascading outages.

Itâ€™s made me wonder whether retries are solving the wrong problem at the wrong layer â€” treating a coordination issue as an application-level error-handling concern.

I wrote up a longer piece exploring this idea and arguing for making failure boring again by handling it at a different layer: https://www.ezthrottle.network/blog/making-failure-boring-again

Curious how this matches othersâ€™ experience:

Have retries actually improved stability for you under sustained rate limiting?

Have you seen cases where they clearly made things worse?

If retries arenâ€™t the right abstraction, what is?

Interested in war stories, counterexamples, and alternative approaches.

Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46841137

Points: 1

articles.title: Ask HN: Gmail/Draft Problems?
articles.description:
I've been using GMail for many years both privately and inside Workspace.

Recently I've had mulitple problems where drafts disappear, sometimes even after I send them. My partner's seen this as well on a completely unrelated workspace enterprise account.

On top of that,I've noticed that my "Drafts" are conspicuously missing entries since mid-November. I've got a pretty good rate of leaving drafts and ideas half formed in email.

(I'm not looking for advice, guidance, or berating for this behavior â€“ I've already gotten an earful from my team.)

Has anyone else seen this? Perhaps take a look in drafts and see what's missing!
